description: From Medieval Latin amalgama (“mercury alloy”), from Arabic اَلْمَلْغَم‎ (al-malḡam, “emollient poultice or unguent for sores”), from Ancient Greek μάλαγμα (málagma, “emollient; malleable material”), from μαλάσσω (malássō, “to soften”), from μαλακός (malakós, “soft”). Doublet of malagma. For the verb, compare French amalgamer.

entries.meaning: One of the ingredients in an alloy.

verbs.description: amalgam (third-person singular simple present amalgams, present participle amalgaming, simple past and past participle amalgamed)

examples: I had once occasion to distill in a small retort some gold amalgamed with such a fine and subtile mercur
